definition[0]: to put something into a liquid and lift it out again
example[0]: He dipped his hand in the water.
example[1]: Dip the strawberries into melted chocolate.
definition[1]: to move down, or to make something move down, usually for just a short time
example[2]: We watched the sun dip below the horizon.
example[3]: She dipped her head and spoke into the microphone.
definition[2]: if an amount or level dips, it becomes less, usually for just a short time
definition[3]: if land or a road or path dips, it slopes down and then goes up again
definition[4]: to put animals in a chemical that kills insects on their skin
example[6]: Are you coming in for a dip?
example[7]: Let’s take a dip in the lake.
definition[6]: a slight decrease in the amount of something
definition[7]: a thick mixture that you can dip food into before you eat it
definition[8]: a place where the surface of something goes down suddenly, then goes up again
definition[9]: a chemical that kills insects on sheep and other animals
definition[11]: to become lower, often before increasing again
example[12]: An oil glut would weaken prices as demand dipped in the spring.
example[13]: Shares in the building and construction group dipped 6p after the company revealed massive losses last year.
example[14]: The group’s annual revenues dipped from $1.36 billion to $1.31 billion.
definition[12]: a decrease in the amount of something
